It’s really sad to see how many negative reviews this game has… I don’t think it’s a fair assessment of the current situation. I've got already 100+ hours in the game and still a lot to do!

I would say, don't be afraid of the mixed reviews - it seems that an early access launch was really rough, and therefore it influenced the current rating, but the dev team has done a great job of squashing the bugs that earned this game so many negative reviews early on.

Anyway, I would like to lay out some pros and cons of this game, so at least you can have a better picture what to expect from this title.


** PROS **

1. The world is truly beautiful, shall I say - almost magical in feeling. It gives you a sense of immersion and the atmosphere is very chilling... Varied biomes - starting from swamps, moving over the forests, plains and ending in the high mountains. I love a very clear map/navigation system - it shows all the tags of visited places (quite similar to Skyrim approach).

2. This is obviously totally open world survival game, so you can go anywhere and do whatever you want.

3. You can tame most of the creatures in the game! You can make an ad-hoc army from wolves while adventuring if you fancy. For a long term companion use scrolls which are extending the loyalty of the creature. You can tame horses, tree-men, dragons, demons, and what not :) Taming is much easier and not as time consuming like in other similar games.

4. Flying! Yes, you can fly in this game not just on a mount but also on a broomstick or just simply with a flying potion. Obviously you can still go back to more “traditional” way of flying - on a back of your very own dragon!

5. Build your house wherever you want. You can build a majestic wizard tower in hard to reach places, or maybe you fancy a more impressive castle - your imagination is your limit. The building system is really good! I would even risk and say, that it is one of the best in comparison to other similar games. The pieces you are building with, they fit together very well, and let you build really complicated shapes as well (e.g. curved walls, etc.). Variety of materials and different furniture packs additionally spicing things up.

6. I really like crafting system, which has a bit of RNG in it, but it gives you a sense of polishing your perfect armor or weapon. RNG is not bad, because if let's say armor pieces have the statistics you don't want, you can put them into deconstructor and regain most of the valuable resources and re-craft! 

7. Magic! This is after all a WIZARD GAME! There are 4 different types of weapons which dictate what kind of spell you can slot: Wands, Staves, Gauntlets and Melee. I really like this approach, with some reservations though, about which I will mention in CONS section. You can swap two weapons in-battle so that gives you 4 different spells you can use during the fight. In terms of abilities themselves, some of them are projectiles, some semi aoe, instant dots, channeled beams - the variety is really outstanding. You can easily choose the specific skill to match your preferred type of strategy.

8. Knowledge system - I also like how you improve your abilities. There are 60 levels in the game (so far). Every level you get knowledge points, which in turn they can be invested in different "trees". You can’t max everything out so you need to work with others, or reset your skills from time to time with a potion.

9. Developers are active in the Steam community - they inform what is in the pipeline, reply on any reported bugs - they just listen to the community. Thumbs up.


** MIXED **

1. No proper end game yet, however there’s a lot of caves and mini dungeons scattered around the world, so the sense of the adventure is there, nevertheless what is missing, is a reward that would excite you. I know though that very recently devs announced a content drop that will give us new dungeons with a proper challenge vs reward - looking forward to it!

2. AI of the creatures… It’s rather bad, you can see that they are trying to avoid your projectiles, they are strafing, but at the same time sometimes they can just stuck and becoming sitting ducks.

3. Sound -  while music is really great in the game (however we need more tracks), the sound is not great. For instance, I hate very abrupt and non-climatic explosion of fireball (kind of a shot gun sound). Also some of the sounds are too loud or are being triggered at the wrong time. There’s a lot of improvement needed in this area.

4. Optimisation - while not bad anymore, it still needs more work. Especially for bigger buildings / constructions the game can be really sluggish, even on a good PC spec.


** CONS **

1. Learning new spells - I like how currently spells are divided between different types of weapons (with a couple branches independent of the weapon). However, how you acquire them is very… shallow for a "wizard sim" type of game. For me this is the biggest complain.

I would love to see the system where you need to study spells (mini games maybe?), during the study let's say you discovered that there is a way to increase effectiveness of fireball but you need to get a really rare ingredient, or control a specific place of power in the word, etc. As a magic user, a player should feel a sense of progression in his or her arcane study. There are no magic experiments - they could add a bit of flavour to the game - e.g. the more dangerous the experiment is, when failed, would give a player some debuffs for a while, but if done right, would give nice bonuses to study new spells, etc. Obviously spell crafting from Oblivion would be my dream come true :) (but no overpowered combinations, please).

2. PvP needs some kind of ''in-world struggle system'' - maybe capturing the resources or places of power? At the moment the only incentive of PvP is raiding the bases and stealing resources - not very innovative.

3. Still long loading times when you first log into the game.

4. No support for economy between players. Maybe addition of marketplace mechanic, where players could visit a town market to buy missing resources from other players’.

5. Animation system - recently much improved, there’s still a lot of room for improvement - e.g. swimming animation which looks a bit silly at the moment.

6. No story driven content. I personally don’t want traditional quests in the game though… What would be great to have, is some kind of procedural generated events that are happening in the world. What would be even better, if these events would influence the world somehow...

7. Game definitely needs more players, hopefully content-drops at some point will lure some population back.

8. Minor bugs


** CONCLUSION **

Really great game! I have easily already got my money's worth for the price tag. Very immersive game, very believable world, amazing building system, sense of progression (but not fully there yet) and when fully fledged dungeons will be added with an upcoming content drop - it will be a really nicely done game. 

On the other hand, if you expect more story driven content - this is not a game for you. You need to organise yourself and decide what to do in this vast and diverse world.

Definitely not worth it for solo/single player.

The spell variety is pretty limited, there's ~25 direct damage spells in total and about half of them are very minor variations on a theme. 

For example, you have:
Arcane Beam - a continuous damage beam
Fire Beam - a continuous damage beam with a minor burn DoT effect. 
Ice Beam - a continuous damage beam with a minor slowing effect
Light Beam - a continuous healing beam 
Nature Beam - a stronger continuous healing beam with a very short range
Dark Beam - a continuous damage beam that costs HP instead of mana
Storm Beam - a continuous damage beam with minor chaining damage.

That's 1/4 of your combat spells.

There's little in the way of debuffing or synergising between spells, so most combat against the AI boils down to picking your most mana efficient spell/weapon combo and running backwards/in-circles whilst hitting them with the same spell over and over, hoping their HP runs out before your mana does. Even on basic mobs you'll want to focus on mana efficiency because basic mana regeneration is achingly slow and crafting mana potions is just more grind, so if you want to engage in back-to-back fights without waiting you'll want to ration it out carefully.

Enemies are... Average. There's a decent number of -technically- different varieties, although they're mostly pretty one-note, you have the flying ones, the melee ones, the ranged ones, the big slow melee ones and when you really push into the end-game you have the teleporting melee ones, the flying ranged ones, and the melee ones that also sometimes fire a ranged spell. Hit boxes and AI pathing are both clunky as hell too, and almost none of them can deal with a player flying directly above them, the only downside of which is the heavy mana-cost of doing both at once.

The grind as a single player is ungodly, so much so that even after cranking the rate of everything to 500% in server options, I still ended up using console commands to largely skip the mid-game when it became obvious that the progression through the tech tree was simply "More of the same, but bigger numbers"

The building looks pretty enough, but is largely useless to a solo player short of having somewhere to place crafting stations and store your junk. It's also pretty expensive, so of course the default is an ugly cramped box rammed full of crafting stations and a respawn circle.

The 3 end-game dungeons were also not well balanced for solo play either. You will need an immense stock of mana/health potions if you want any hope of depleting the massive health pools in the allotted time before the dungeon kicks you out, and even then expect a boring too-long fight running in circles slugging it out with the final boss at the end.

Exploring was underwhelming, there are a good few "biome" styles around the map, but everything felt a bit lifeless. And the NPCs constantly scattered in random little empty stone huts, asking you to "kill/tame/harvest X of Y for an XP/item reward" being pretty much the only interactive NPCs on the map outside of the tutorial is pretty lackluster.

Taming seems fun but doesn't really add much to the game. Pets move very slowly as mounts and aren't effective in combat. Once they die, they're dead. No way to bring them back.

World seems very large but is very empty, with only scattered enemy camps (a group of 2+ enemies) or "dungeons" which are sometimes just a single room in a cave. Even the slightly larger caves don't offer much except a few monster spawns and no real reason to revisit them.
